full_text:
Sustain The “Tunisia Innovation Network”

Title
null
Please provide a name for your action learning plan.

Sustain The “Tunisia Innovation Network”
Challenge statement
null
Challenge type: If you are working on multiple challenges, please indicate if this is your "big bet" or "exploratory" challenge. 

Please note: we ask you to only submit a maximum of 3 challenges - 1x Big Bet, 2x Exploratory. Each challenge must be submitted individually.

BIG BET

Challenge statement: What is your challenge? (Please answer in specific terms: "Our challenge is that...”.)

Our challenge is that The “Tunisia Innovation Network” is set to expand into universities with a special focus on AI.

Background: What is the history of your challenge? What is causing or driving it? Who is involved? How does the current situation look like? What undesired effects does it produce?

This network is one of the flagship programs of the Lab, the challenge of 2024 was the animation, sustainability and codification of the network.

Through monthly Calls, online training with international consultants, and two physical meetings, one of which was with government representatives, as well as immersion in the UN environment, the network is now ready to begin collective experiments with the aim of incorporating innovation into public policies.



"Tunisia Innovation Network" Training on pitching

"Tunisia Innovation Network" Training on pitching



Value proposition: What added value or unique value proposition is your Accelerator Lab bringing to solving this challenge? Why is it your Lab that needs to work on this challenge and not other actors within UNDP, other stakeholders in the country respectively? Why is it worth investing resources to this challenge?

The “Tunisia Innovation Network” is a flagship initiative of UNDP Tunisia. The aim is to provide the country with a multidisciplinary network to positively influence public policy. It's a cross-functional initiative in line with the Acceleretor lab's core mission of dissemination and impact through innovation.

Short “tweet” summary: We would like to tweet what you are working on, can you summarize your challenge in a maximum of 280 characters?

The “Tunisia Innovation Network” is an initiative of UNDP Tunisia's Accelerator Lab, which federates capabilities and innovators in several development fields. They are ready to deploy their innovations in Tunisian universities.
Challenge classification
null
Click to see options
thematic_areas: accelerator lab
thematic_areas: innovation
thematic_areas: innovation ecosystem
thematic_areas: policy innovation
thematic_areas: policy making
thematic_areas: public policy planning
thematic_areas: public sector innovation

Click to see options
sdgs: Industry, innovation and infrastructure
sdgs: Sustainable cities and communities
sdgs: Partnerships for the goals
Partners
null
Please state the name of the partner:

University of Jendouba, university of Monastir, university of Sousse, direction des politiques publiques à la présidence du gouvernement, Maarifa for Transition

What sector does our partner belong to?

Academia

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.

Universities play a pivotal role in desiminating innovation among students and young people. This is the ideal place to disseminate the Accelerator Lab's tools and the innovation network it has created.

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?

No
Learning questions
null
Learning question: What is your learning question for this challenge? What do you need to know or understand to work on your challenge statement?

Will the codification of a network of innovators ex nihilo enable the dissemination of innovative tools to the population, particularly young people, and have an impact on public policy?

To what stage(s) in the learning cycle does your learning question relate?

Test

Click to see options
methods: Co-creation
methods: Collective Intelligence
methods: Design Thinking
methods: Human Centered Design
methods: innovation challenges

Usage of methods: Relating to your choice above, how will you use your methods & tools for this learning question? What value do these add in answering your learning question?

The network creation phase between members who didn't know each other was a real challenge, requiring the use of design thinking and collective intelligence tools to bond and explore the group's capabilities

Click to see options
datasources: co-creation
datasources: co-designing
datasources: collective imagination
datasources: collective intelligence
datasources: design thinking
datasources: ecosystem mapping

Existing data gaps: Relating to your choice above, what existing gaps in data or information do these new sources of data addressing? What value do these add in answering your learning question?

No mapping or studies of the innovation ecosystem in Tunisia
Closing
null
Early leads to grow: Think about the possible grow phase for this challenge - who might benefit from your work on this challenge or who might be the champions in your country that you should inform or collaborate with early on to help you grow this challenge?

Firstly, the network members themselves will benefit from the exchanges and feedback they have had, and all those targeted by the network's activities, in particular students. UNDP also benefits from expanding its aura and reputation as a key player in innovation in Tunisia.

"}, {"id": "48be40ee-12ab-47a1-9571-0f026522e1cb", "txt": "Our challenge is that the UNDP Viet Nam AccLab and CO need to fundraise and establish a cost-recovery mechanism for our activities to ensure Lab sustainability and continued viability ", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": true, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Challenge statement: What is your challenge? (Please answer in specific terms: "Our challenge is that...”.)

"}, {"id": "fa19b906-7c86-4e8a-9f16-7b236d2e6bb8", "txt": "Over the past decades, Viet Nam has experienced rapid economic growth, transitioning from a low-income to a low-middle-income country. While this progress is a positive milestone, it has led to a significant decline in Official Development Assistance (ODA), as international donors shift their focus to lower-income nations. As a result, UNDP Viet Nam and the Accelerator Lab must explore alternative funding models to sustain our work in driving innovation for sustainable development. 

This challenge is further compounded by a global decline in international development funding, as donor priorities shift towards domestic concerns and emerging global crises. Development organizations worldwide are facing increased pressure to demonstrate financial sustainability and justify their value proposition beyond traditional models. 

At the same time, Viet Nam is undergoing a major political restructuring under its new leadership. While this has created a temporary bureaucratic freeze, there are emerging policy opportunities, particularly with Resolutions 57 and 03, which signal a strong governmental push for science, technology, and innovation (STI). This shift presents a window for the Lab to position itself as a key partner in Viet Nam’s innovation landscape. 

However, a fundamental challenge remains: Viet Nam’s government has historically not paid for UN services. Unlike the private sector or donor-funded initiatives, government institutions are accustomed to receiving ODA rather than using their own budgets to procure services from international organizations. This lack of precedent presents both a mindset and structural barrier to positioning UNDP and the Accelerator Lab as a viable service provider in innovation consulting. 

As a result, the current situation produces several undesired effects: 

- Uncertain financial sustainability of the Lab beyond 2025, risking a loss of innovation capacity within UNDP Viet Nam. 

- Limited agility in responding to local needs, as reliance on donor funding dictates priorities rather than market-driven demand. 

- Missed opportunities for client partnership with the Vietnamese government, as existing UNDP support is often viewed through the lens of donor-funded technical assistance rather than as a strategic service offering. 

- To overcome these challenges, the Lab must navigate a fundamental shift in how it operates—transforming from a donor-dependent initiative into a financially sustainable, market-responsive innovation service provider. ", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Background: What is the history of your challenge? What is causing or driving it? Who is involved? How does the current situation look like? What undesired effects does it produce?

"}, {"id": "fc667bf3-0bc8-41c8-900b-8846fef3222e", "name": null, "type": "group", "items": [[{"id": "45c2f1c7-0640-4562-89b5-c541ae3e8a56", "txt": "Declining ODA and Shifting Donor Priorities: 
Between 2000 and 2020, Vietnam was a major recipient of Official Development Assistance (ODA), receiving between $1 – $4 billion annually.  According to the DevelopmentAid Country Report on Vietnam (2018), Vietnam’s net Official Development Assistance as a percentage of GDP has steadily declined as the country’s robust economic growth has gradually reduced its aid dependency due to Vietnam's improved human development indicators and its entry into middle-income country status.  .   

Financing Challenges and IDA Graduation: 
The Oxfam Library report on Financing Development in Vietnam offers an in-depth analysis of Vietnam’s shift away from concessional financing as it nears IDA graduation. This report details how key donors—including Japan, USAID, and the EU—are adjusting their portfolios, leading to significant reductions in concessional aid. Such recalibration underscores the urgency for Vietnam to explore alternative funding mechanisms to sustain its development agenda. 

Innovation Policy and R&D Investment: 
Recent policy moves, such as Vietnam’s Resolution 57-NQ/TW (2023) and Resolution 03/NQ-CP (2024), aim to boost the nation’s innovation ecosystem by enhancing digital transformation and public–private partnerships. Meanwhile, World Bank data indicate that current R&D investment is around 0.5% of GDP, with a target of 2% by 2030—an ambitious goal to drive sustainable economic transformation. ", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": false, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": ""}, {"id": "9ca8bdba-cf1b-48fd-872f-b019d0d5fb74", "src": null, "html": "", "name": null, "type": "embed", "level": "media", "required": false, "textalign": "left", "has_content": false, "instruction": ""}, {"id": "5b0edd22-f7cc-4d9c-9f6b-2ac95cf86bae", "src": null, "name": null, "type": "img", "level": "media", "scale": "original", "required": false, "textalign": "center", "has_content": false, "instruction": ""}]], "level": "media", "structure": [{"id": "45c2f1c7-0640-4562-89b5-c541ae3e8a56", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "editable": true, "required": false, "is_excerpt": false, "instruction": ""}, {"id": "9ca8bdba-cf1b-48fd-872f-b019d0d5fb74", "name": null, "type": "embed", "level": "media", "editable": true, "required": false, "instruction": ""}, {"id": "5b0edd22-f7cc-4d9c-9f6b-2ac95cf86bae", "name": null, "type": "img", "level": "media", "editable": true, "required": false, "instruction": ""}], "instruction": "Quantitative evidence: What (official) data sources do you have on this challenge that better exemplifies the importance and urgency of this frontier challenge? You can add text, a link, or a picture.
"}, {"id": "fe77e584-abcc-4d29-9ded-9dd09ee4e8ca", "name": null, "type": "group", "items": [[{"id": "ac86f88e-6d60-432b-828f-b849c40a7b2d", "txt": "Our existing relationship with government partner such as the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST), the National Innovation Center (NIC), and provincial such as Danang and Hue hint at a growing interest in leveraging UNDP expertise for innovation consulting. This is something we have done for free in previous years, but it can be potential entry point for UNDP’s services. 

New leadership in Vietnam and a strong push in innovation and technology such as with Resolution 57 and 03 in 2024-2025 to push investment in R&D indicate a room of opportunity       ", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": false, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": ""}, {"id": "aea972c1-0eb8-4b0b-87cf-fb394c246bf8", "src": null, "html": "", "name": null, "type": "embed", "level": "media", "required": false, "textalign": "left", "has_content": false, "instruction": ""}, {"id": "6fca277f-9fb1-428a-b2f1-91cd42f51981", "src": null, "name": null, "type": "img", "level": "media", "scale": "original", "required": false, "textalign": "center", "has_content": false, "instruction": ""}]], "level": "media", "structure": [{"id": "ac86f88e-6d60-432b-828f-b849c40a7b2d", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "editable": true, "required": false, "is_excerpt": false, "instruction": ""}, {"id": "aea972c1-0eb8-4b0b-87cf-fb394c246bf8", "name": null, "type": "embed", "level": "media", "editable": true, "required": false, "instruction": ""}, {"id": "6fca277f-9fb1-428a-b2f1-91cd42f51981", "name": null, "type": "img", "level": "media", "editable": true, "required": false, "instruction": ""}], "instruction": "Qualitative evidence: What weak signals have you recently spotted that characterizes its urgency? Please provide qualitative information that better exemplifies the importance and urgency of this frontier challenge. You can add text, a link, or a picture.
"}, {"id": "8bf9a24d-d76b-4ea2-9ae8-5011f95b87ee", "txt": "The UNDP Accelerator Lab Viet Nam brings a unique, systems-focused approach to innovation that sets it apart from traditional development actors, private sector consultancies, and government agencies. Our five years of on-the-ground experimentation, deep contextual knowledge, and global network of 90+ Labs uniquely position us to tackle this challenge. 

 

1. A Proven Track Record in Innovation & Experimentation 

The Lab has pioneered lean experimentation, solutions mapping, and systems thinking to address complex challenges in circular economy waste management, digital transformation, and public sector innovation. 

Unlike traditional UNDP country programs, which focus on policy advocacy and large-scale interventions, the Lab is agile, adaptive, and iterative—able to prototype, test, and refine innovation models before scaling. 

 

2. Bridging the Gap Between Government, Development, and Market-driven Innovation 

The Vietnamese government recognizes the need for innovation but lacks the internal capacity to design and execute human-centered, experimental approaches. 

Private sector consultancies provide innovation services but are often detached from local development needs and lack a sustainability lens. 

The Accelerator Lab operates at the intersection of these two spaces—leveraging UNDP’s policy credibility while offering the agility and problem-solving mindset of a start-up. 

3. Global Knowledge + Local Application 

Through the UNDP Accelerator Labs network, we have access to cutting-edge methodologies, global case studies, and peer-to-peer learning opportunities, ensuring that Viet Nam benefits from global best practices. 

Our deep contextual expertise in Viet Nam’s unique governance, economic, and cultural landscape allows us to localize and tailor innovation services in ways that international consulting firms cannot. 

4. A Unique and Sustainable Business Model 

Unlike traditional UNDP programs, which rely on ODA and donor grants, the Lab’s new fee-for-service model will create financial sustainability, reducing reliance on external funding. 

This approach aligns with the Vietnamese government’s push for public-private partnerships in innovation, creating an opportunity to mainstream innovation services as a strategic investment rather than a donor-funded activity. ", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Value proposition: What added value or unique value proposition is your Accelerator Lab bringing to solving this challenge? Why is it your Lab that needs to work on this challenge and not other actors within UNDP, other stakeholders in the country respectively? Why is it worth investing resources to this challenge?

"}, {"id": "5c9384fd-5f55-4865-8d25-93ea7f0f766a", "txt": "💡 As Viet Nam transitions to a middle-income country, The UNDP Accelerator Lab is pioneering a market-fit innovation service to sustain impact beyond 2025—monetizing our expertise to support gov, businesses & development partners. #Innovation4SDGs ", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "constraint": 280, "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Short “tweet” summary: We would like to tweet what you are working on, can you summarize your challenge in a maximum of 280 characters?

"}]}, {"id": "cafe90a5-dca3-43dc-a904-e9f88d365110", "lead": "", "type": "section", "items": [{"id": "f1767e5d-adda-4bdd-9a63-59a0e341b34a", "name": null, "type": "group", "items": [[{"id": "e7f8f93f-62cf-45d1-acbf-5b823e8d7310", "txt": "Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) – Public Sector (Government Innovation & STI Policy)

MOST is the leading government agency responsible for science, technology, and innovation (STI) in Viet Nam. Given the push from Resolution 57 & 03, MOST is actively seeking mechanisms to advance innovation and R&D commercialization.



National Innovation Center (NIC) – Public-Private Innovation Hub

NIC is Viet Nam’s premier government-backed innovation ecosystem, focusing on R&D, digital transformation, and startup acceleration.



Large Private Sector Firms (e.g., FPT, VNG, VinGroup Ventures) – Private Sector (Technology & R&D Investment)

Vietnamese tech conglomerates and corporate venture funds are investing heavily in R&D, digital transformation, and sustainability but lack structured innovation processes.



National Economics University (NEU) Fulbright University Viet Nam (FUV) – Academia (Public Policy & Anticipatory Governance)

To design a market-fit innovation service, we need to fill critical information gaps about demand, feasibility, pricing, and operational models for monetizing UNDP innovation services in Viet Nam. Below are key data gaps and how our selected innovation methods will address them:

 Market Demand & Willingness to Pay for Innovation Services

  Data Gap:

What specific innovation services are in demand by government agencies, businesses, and donors in Viet Nam?
Are these stakeholders willing to pay, and if so, how much?

 How We Address It:

Human-Centered Design & Behavioral Insights → Conduct deep listening & user research to understand government and business needs.
Lean Experimentation → Pilot small-scale paid services to test demand and validate pricing.
Business Model Innovation → Use competitive benchmarking to identify how similar innovation services are monetized elsewhere.

 Value Added:
Provides real-world insights into which services have market potential and at what price points, ensuring we don’t create services that no one will buy.", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Existing data gaps: Relating to your choice above, what existing gaps in data or information do these new sources of data addressing? Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) – Leads Viet Nam’s science, technology, and innovation (STI) policies and is actively seeking innovation partnerships under Resolution 57 & 03. 

National Innovation Center (NIC) – Viet Nam’s flagship hub for tech and innovation; potential co-developer or client for innovation services. 

Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) – Oversees economic development policies; key for integrating innovation into national development planning. 

Local Governments (e.g., Da Nang, HCMC, Hanoi People’s Committees) – Cities with strong interest in urban innovation, circular economy, and digital transformation. 

2.  Private Sector & Innovation Ecosystem 

Tech Corporations & Impact Investors (e.g., FPT, VNG, VinGroup Ventures) – Large Vietnamese firms investing in R&D and could co-develop or procure UNDP innovation services. 

Startup Ecosystem (e.g., BK Holdings, Zone Startups, Sun Startups)* – Potential partners for co-creating and piloting innovation models. 

Chambers of Commerce (e.g., EuroCham, AmCham, Vietnam Business Forum) – Bridge to foreign enterprises interested in sustainable innovation solutions. 

3. Development & Multilateral Organizations 

Bilateral Donors (e.g., USAID, GIZ, ADB, World Bank) – Some donors are shifting from ODA grants to innovation funding models, presenting an opportunity for cost-sharing. 

UNDP Global & Regional Innovation Teams – Can provide guidance on fee-for-service models and lessons learned from other country offices. 

4. Academia & Research Institutions 

Vietnam National University (VNU), Fulbright University Viet Nam (FUV) – Potential partners for co-developing innovation methodologies and training programs. 

Think Tanks & Policy Labs (e.g., NEU’s Anticipatory Governance Initiative) – Provide policy insights and open doors to government collaboration.

full_text:
Finding Market-fit Service Offering for Vietnam AccLab

Title
null
Please provide a name for your action learning plan.
Localize a Market-fit Offer for Vietnam AccLab Innovation Service
Challenge statement
null
Challenge type: If you are working on multiple challenges, please indicate if this is your "big bet" or "exploratory" challenge. 

Please note: we ask you to only submit a maximum of 3 challenges - 1x Big Bet, 2x Exploratory. Each challenge must be submitted individually.
BIG BET

Challenge statement: What is your challenge? (Please answer in specific terms: "Our challenge is that...”.)
Our challenge is that the UNDP Viet Nam AccLab and CO need to fundraise and establish a cost-recovery mechanism for our activities to ensure Lab sustainability and continued viability

Background: What is the history of your challenge? What is causing or driving it? Who is involved? How does the current situation look like? What undesired effects does it produce?
Over the past decades, Viet Nam has experienced rapid economic growth, transitioning from a low-income to a low-middle-income country. While this progress is a positive milestone, it has led to a significant decline in Official Development Assistance (ODA), as international donors shift their focus to lower-income nations. As a result, UNDP Viet Nam and the Accelerator Lab must explore alternative funding models to sustain our work in driving innovation for sustainable development. 

This challenge is further compounded by a global decline in international development funding, as donor priorities shift towards domestic concerns and emerging global crises. Development organizations worldwide are facing increased pressure to demonstrate financial sustainability and justify their value proposition beyond traditional models. 

At the same time, Viet Nam is undergoing a major political restructuring under its new leadership. While this has created a temporary bureaucratic freeze, there are emerging policy opportunities, particularly with Resolutions 57 and 03, which signal a strong governmental push for science, technology, and innovation (STI). This shift presents a window for the Lab to position itself as a key partner in Viet Nam’s innovation landscape. 

However, a fundamental challenge remains: Viet Nam’s government has historically not paid for UN services. Unlike the private sector or donor-funded initiatives, government institutions are accustomed to receiving ODA rather than using their own budgets to procure services from international organizations. This lack of precedent presents both a mindset and structural barrier to positioning UNDP and the Accelerator Lab as a viable service provider in innovation consulting. 

As a result, the current situation produces several undesired effects: 

- Uncertain financial sustainability of the Lab beyond 2025, risking a loss of innovation capacity within UNDP Viet Nam. 

- Limited agility in responding to local needs, as reliance on donor funding dictates priorities rather than market-driven demand. 

- Missed opportunities for client partnership with the Vietnamese government, as existing UNDP support is often viewed through the lens of donor-funded technical assistance rather than as a strategic service offering. 

- To overcome these challenges, the Lab must navigate a fundamental shift in how it operates—transforming from a donor-dependent initiative into a financially sustainable, market-responsive innovation service provider.

Declining ODA and Shifting Donor Priorities: 
Between 2000 and 2020, Vietnam was a major recipient of Official Development Assistance (ODA), receiving between $1 – $4 billion annually.  According to the DevelopmentAid Country Report on Vietnam (2018), Vietnam’s net Official Development Assistance as a percentage of GDP has steadily declined as the country’s robust economic growth has gradually reduced its aid dependency due to Vietnam's improved human development indicators and its entry into middle-income country status.  .   

Financing Challenges and IDA Graduation: 
The Oxfam Library report on Financing Development in Vietnam offers an in-depth analysis of Vietnam’s shift away from concessional financing as it nears IDA graduation. This report details how key donors—including Japan, USAID, and the EU—are adjusting their portfolios, leading to significant reductions in concessional aid. Such recalibration underscores the urgency for Vietnam to explore alternative funding mechanisms to sustain its development agenda. 

Innovation Policy and R&D Investment: 
Recent policy moves, such as Vietnam’s Resolution 57-NQ/TW (2023) and Resolution 03/NQ-CP (2024), aim to boost the nation’s innovation ecosystem by enhancing digital transformation and public–private partnerships. Meanwhile, World Bank data indicate that current R&D investment is around 0.5% of GDP, with a target of 2% by 2030—an ambitious goal to drive sustainable economic transformation.



Our existing relationship with government partner such as the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST), the National Innovation Center (NIC), and provincial such as Danang and Hue hint at a growing interest in leveraging UNDP expertise for innovation consulting. This is something we have done for free in previous years, but it can be potential entry point for UNDP’s services. 

New leadership in Vietnam and a strong push in innovation and technology such as with Resolution 57 and 03 in 2024-2025 to push investment in R&D indicate a room of opportunity



Value proposition: What added value or unique value proposition is your Accelerator Lab bringing to solving this challenge? Why is it your Lab that needs to work on this challenge and not other actors within UNDP, other stakeholders in the country respectively? Why is it worth investing resources to this challenge?
The UNDP Accelerator Lab Viet Nam brings a unique, systems-focused approach to innovation that sets it apart from traditional development actors, private sector consultancies, and government agencies. Our five years of on-the-ground experimentation, deep contextual knowledge, and global network of 90+ Labs uniquely position us to tackle this challenge. 

 

1. A Proven Track Record in Innovation & Experimentation 

The Lab has pioneered lean experimentation, solutions mapping, and systems thinking to address complex challenges in circular economy waste management, digital transformation, and public sector innovation. 

Unlike traditional UNDP country programs, which focus on policy advocacy and large-scale interventions, the Lab is agile, adaptive, and iterative—able to prototype, test, and refine innovation models before scaling. 

 

2. Bridging the Gap Between Government, Development, and Market-driven Innovation 

The Vietnamese government recognizes the need for innovation but lacks the internal capacity to design and execute human-centered, experimental approaches. 

Private sector consultancies provide innovation services but are often detached from local development needs and lack a sustainability lens. 

The Accelerator Lab operates at the intersection of these two spaces—leveraging UNDP’s policy credibility while offering the agility and problem-solving mindset of a start-up. 

3. Global Knowledge + Local Application 

Through the UNDP Accelerator Labs network, we have access to cutting-edge methodologies, global case studies, and peer-to-peer learning opportunities, ensuring that Viet Nam benefits from global best practices. 

Our deep contextual expertise in Viet Nam’s unique governance, economic, and cultural landscape allows us to localize and tailor innovation services in ways that international consulting firms cannot. 

4. A Unique and Sustainable Business Model 

Unlike traditional UNDP programs, which rely on ODA and donor grants, the Lab’s new fee-for-service model will create financial sustainability, reducing reliance on external funding. 

This approach aligns with the Vietnamese government’s push for public-private partnerships in innovation, creating an opportunity to mainstream innovation services as a strategic investment rather than a donor-funded activity.

Short “tweet” summary: We would like to tweet what you are working on, can you summarize your challenge in a maximum of 280 characters?
💡 As Viet Nam transitions to a middle-income country, The UNDP Accelerator Lab is pioneering a market-fit innovation service to sustain impact beyond 2025—monetizing our expertise to support gov, businesses & development partners. #Innovation4SDGs

Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) – Public Sector (Government Innovation & STI Policy)

MOST is the leading government agency responsible for science, technology, and innovation (STI) in Viet Nam. Given the push from Resolution 57 & 03, MOST is actively seeking mechanisms to advance innovation and R&D commercialization.



National Innovation Center (NIC) – Public-Private Innovation Hub

NIC is Viet Nam’s premier government-backed innovation ecosystem, focusing on R&D, digital transformation, and startup acceleration.



Large Private Sector Firms (e.g., FPT, VNG, VinGroup Ventures) – Private Sector (Technology & R&D Investment)

Vietnamese tech conglomerates and corporate venture funds are investing heavily in R&D, digital transformation, and sustainability but lack structured innovation processes.



National Economics University (NEU) Fulbright University Viet Nam (FUV) – Academia (Public Policy & Anticipatory Governance)

What sector does our partner belong to?
Government (&related)

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.
With Gov: Position the Accelerator Lab as an innovation service provider for MOST’s initiatives, offering systems mapping, foresight, and experimentation services to test and scale national STI policies.

 Partner with NIC to co-develop and pilot fee-based innovation services, embedding UNDP’s expertise in policy experimentation, circular economy, and digital innovation within NIC’s existing programs.



With Corporate: Offer systems innovation, prototyping, and behavioral insight services to help businesses test and de-risk innovation initiatives, embedding UNDP’s expertise into corporate R&D strategies.



With Universities: Partner with university on innovation capacity-building programs, conduct joint research on public sector innovation, and leverage private sector networks to expand innovation service offerings.

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?
No
Learning questions

Learning question: What is your learning question for this challenge? What do you need to know or understand to work on your challenge statement?
How can the UNDP Accelerator Lab Viet Nam design, test, and operationalize a market-fit innovation service that is both financially viable and aligned with Viet Nam’s development priorities, while navigating government procurement barriers and a historically donor-dependent system?

To what stage(s) in the learning cycle does your learning question relate?

Business Model Innovation & Cost Recovery Strategies

🔹 Why? To develop a sustainable revenue model for UNDP’s innovation services in Viet Nam.
🔹 How?

Explore different pricing strategies (e.g., fee-for-service, subscription, PPPs).
Learn from UNDP country offices & global innovation hubs that have tested cost-recovery models.
🔹 Tool: Business Model Canvas + UNDP Cost Recovery Framework.

datasources: digital

Existing data gaps: Relating to your choice above, what existing gaps in data or information do these new sources of data addressing? What value do these add in answering your learning question?
Existing Data Gaps & How Our Innovation Methods Address Them

To design a market-fit innovation service, we need to fill critical information gaps about demand, feasibility, pricing, and operational models for monetizing UNDP innovation services in Viet Nam. Below are key data gaps and how our selected innovation methods will address them:

 Market Demand & Willingness to Pay for Innovation Services

  Data Gap:

What specific innovation services are in demand by government agencies, businesses, and donors in Viet Nam?
Are these stakeholders willing to pay, and if so, how much?

 How We Address It:

Human-Centered Design & Behavioral Insights → Conduct deep listening & user research to understand government and business needs.
Lean Experimentation → Pilot small-scale paid services to test demand and validate pricing.
Business Model Innovation → Use competitive benchmarking to identify how similar innovation services are monetized elsewhere.

 Value Added:
Provides real-world insights into which services have market potential and at what price points, ensuring we don’t create services that no one will buy.
Closing
null
Early leads to grow: Think about the possible grow phase for this challenge - who might benefit from your work on this challenge or who might be the champions in your country that you should inform or collaborate with early on to help you grow this challenge?
1. Government Partners (Policy & Public Sector Innovation) 

Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) – Leads Viet Nam’s science, technology, and innovation (STI) policies and is actively seeking innovation partnerships under Resolution 57 & 03. 

National Innovation Center (NIC) – Viet Nam’s flagship hub for tech and innovation; potential co-developer or client for innovation services. 

Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) – Oversees economic development policies; key for integrating innovation into national development planning. 

Local Governments (e.g., Da Nang, HCMC, Hanoi People’s Committees) – Cities with strong interest in urban innovation, circular economy, and digital transformation. 

2.  Private Sector & Innovation Ecosystem 

Tech Corporations & Impact Investors (e.g., FPT, VNG, VinGroup Ventures) – Large Vietnamese firms investing in R&D and could co-develop or procure UNDP innovation services. 

Startup Ecosystem (e.g., BK Holdings, Zone Startups, Sun Startups)* – Potential partners for co-creating and piloting innovation models. 

Chambers of Commerce (e.g., EuroCham, AmCham, Vietnam Business Forum) – Bridge to foreign enterprises interested in sustainable innovation solutions. 

3. Development & Multilateral Organizations 

Bilateral Donors (e.g., USAID, GIZ, ADB, World Bank) – Some donors are shifting from ODA grants to innovation funding models, presenting an opportunity for cost-sharing. 

UNDP Global & Regional Innovation Teams – Can provide guidance on fee-for-service models and lessons learned from other country offices. 

4. Academia & Research Institutions 

Vietnam National University (VNU), Fulbright University Viet Nam (FUV) – Potential partners for co-developing innovation methodologies and training programs. 

Think Tanks & Policy Labs (e.g., NEU’s Anticipatory Governance Initiative) – Provide policy insights and open doors to government collaboration.

title: Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan: Experimenting AI-powered Data Framework as a Transformative Tool

"}, {"id": "48be40ee-12ab-47a1-9571-0f026522e1cb", "txt": "Our challenge is that despite being a country with tremendous tourism potential, Bangladesh is not being able to take the full advantage of it. In 2023, over 30 million domestic and 655,000 foreign tourists vacationed in Bangladesh, marking the country's immense potential to become a ‘Tourism Hotspot’ of Southeast Asia.[1] Despite this, there is no integrated tourist database, resulting in a holistic data sharing framework. Such lack in a National Data Framework in tourism sector hinders data-driven decision making for policymakers to implement Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan. 
", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": true, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Challenge statement: What is your challenge? (Please answer in specific terms: "Our challenge is that...”.)

"}, {"id": "fa19b906-7c86-4e8a-9f16-7b236d2e6bb8", "txt": "Bangladesh, with its rich cultural heritage, stunning landscapes, Cox’s Bazar—the world’s longest sea beach—and the Sundarbans, holds immense tourism potential. However, poor stakeholder coordination and data gaps hinder progress in this sector. The Travel & Tourism Development Index 2024 ranks Bangladesh the lowest in South Asia for policies enabling sustainable tourism development, underscoring urgent reform needs. To establish Bangladesh as a sustainable and inclusive global tourism hub, the Bangladesh Tourism Board (BTB) developed a 25-year Master Plan. Data gaps in areas like sustainable tourism, traditional local products sources and visitor expectations led to a strategic collaboration between BTB and UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab for informed policy development and implementation.", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Background: What is the history of your challenge? What is causing or driving it? Who is involved? How does the current situation look like? What undesired effects does it produce?

"}, {"id": "fc667bf3-0bc8-41c8-900b-8846fef3222e", "name": null, "type": "group", "items": [[{"id": "45c2f1c7-0640-4562-89b5-c541ae3e8a56", "txt": "In Bangladesh, tourism sector contributes slightly greater than 3% in the national GDP, whereas Maldives one-third of the national GDP is contributed by the tourism sector. Approximately, 5 million people are directly or indirectly engaged in the tourism sector of Bangladesh and additional 2 million workforce will be added in this sector gradually within 2030. Despite immense potential and natural resources, Bangladesh is unable to reap the full benefits of tourism due to lack of centralized data framework and a holistic tourism plan.
 
https://www.undp.org/bangladesh/blog/mapping-tourists-mind-introduce-and-nurture-data-driven-decision-making-culture-tourism-sector-creating-informal-employment

"}, {"id": "fe77e584-abcc-4d29-9ded-9dd09ee4e8ca", "name": null, "type": "group", "items": [[{"id": "ac86f88e-6d60-432b-828f-b849c40a7b2d", "txt": "Bangladesh is endowed with remarkable natural beauty, yet the country has struggled to harness its tourism sector as a major contributor to GDP. Unregulated and unplanned growth has led to the absence of a centralized tourism information hub and ineffective policy implementation. The lack of data innovation and real-time analytics has hindered understanding of tourist preferences, sustainable practices, and personalization. With the rising popularity of adventure and Community-Based Tourism (CBT), there is an urgent need for data-driven solutions and AI-powered innovations to elevate the sector and ensure its sustainable growth.

"}, {"id": "8bf9a24d-d76b-4ea2-9ae8-5011f95b87ee", "txt": "UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab has conducted experiments on CBT, data innovation, system thinking and AI intervention. The Accelerator Lab has strong collaboration with Bangladesh Tourism Board (BTB) and both parties jointly conducted relevant interventions in multiple locations of the country. The lab also contributed to formulating in Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan which outlines a 25-year strategy to position the country as a premier global tourist destination by 2041. UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab is uniquely positioned to contribute to developing a National Data Framework to implement Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan in collaboration with relevant stakeholders. From its multilateral partnership, the Accelerator Lab is also positioned to bring in Government agencies, private sector stakeholders, industry association for their participation and organizational buy-in. The Lab will also connect relevant Global Accelerator Labs for knowledge and experience sharing. Previously, UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab collaborated with UNDP Thailand acceleration Lab on sharing learning and experience on community-based tourism. These global knowledge sharing adds tremendous value in such initiatives. Lab will also leverage Artificial Intelligence in implementation of the Tourism Master Plan.
 
https://file.portal.gov.bd/uploads/8ef2a505-c131-4a8f-b6d0-2ac4760cc936/631/6c4/06a/6316c406a9807875210649.pdf

full_text:
Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan: Experimenting AI-powered Data Framework as a Transformative Tool

Title
null
Please provide a name for your action learning plan.
Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan: Experimenting AI-powered Data Framework as a Transformative Tool
Challenge statement
null
Challenge type: If you are working on multiple challenges, please indicate if this is your "big bet" or "exploratory" challenge. 

Please note: we ask you to only submit a maximum of 3 challenges - 1x Big Bet, 2x Exploratory. Each challenge must be submitted individually.
EXPLORATORY

Challenge statement: What is your challenge? (Please answer in specific terms: "Our challenge is that...”.)
Our challenge is that despite being a country with tremendous tourism potential, Bangladesh is not being able to take the full advantage of it. In 2023, over 30 million domestic and 655,000 foreign tourists vacationed in Bangladesh, marking the country's immense potential to become a ‘Tourism Hotspot’ of Southeast Asia.[1] Despite this, there is no integrated tourist database, resulting in a holistic data sharing framework. Such lack in a National Data Framework in tourism sector hinders data-driven decision making for policymakers to implement Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan.

Background: What is the history of your challenge? What is causing or driving it? Who is involved? How does the current situation look like? What undesired effects does it produce?
Bangladesh, with its rich cultural heritage, stunning landscapes, Cox’s Bazar—the world’s longest sea beach—and the Sundarbans, holds immense tourism potential. However, poor stakeholder coordination and data gaps hinder progress in this sector. The Travel & Tourism Development Index 2024 ranks Bangladesh the lowest in South Asia for policies enabling sustainable tourism development, underscoring urgent reform needs. To establish Bangladesh as a sustainable and inclusive global tourism hub, the Bangladesh Tourism Board (BTB) developed a 25-year Master Plan. Data gaps in areas like sustainable tourism, traditional local products sources and visitor expectations led to a strategic collaboration between BTB and UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab for informed policy development and implementation.

In Bangladesh, tourism sector contributes slightly greater than 3% in the national GDP, whereas Maldives one-third of the national GDP is contributed by the tourism sector. Approximately, 5 million people are directly or indirectly engaged in the tourism sector of Bangladesh and additional 2 million workforce will be added in this sector gradually within 2030. Despite immense potential and natural resources, Bangladesh is unable to reap the full benefits of tourism due to lack of centralized data framework and a holistic tourism plan.
 
https://www.undp.org/bangladesh/blog/mapping-tourists-mind-introduce-and-nurture-data-driven-decision-making-culture-tourism-sector-creating-informal-employment



Bangladesh is endowed with remarkable natural beauty, yet the country has struggled to harness its tourism sector as a major contributor to GDP. Unregulated and unplanned growth has led to the absence of a centralized tourism information hub and ineffective policy implementation. The lack of data innovation and real-time analytics has hindered understanding of tourist preferences, sustainable practices, and personalization. With the rising popularity of adventure and Community-Based Tourism (CBT), there is an urgent need for data-driven solutions and AI-powered innovations to elevate the sector and ensure its sustainable growth.



Value proposition: What added value or unique value proposition is your Accelerator Lab bringing to solving this challenge? Why is it your Lab that needs to work on this challenge and not other actors within UNDP, other stakeholders in the country respectively? Why is it worth investing resources to this challenge?
UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab has conducted experiments on CBT, data innovation, system thinking and AI intervention. The Accelerator Lab has strong collaboration with Bangladesh Tourism Board (BTB) and both parties jointly conducted relevant interventions in multiple locations of the country. The lab also contributed to formulating in Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan which outlines a 25-year strategy to position the country as a premier global tourist destination by 2041. UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab is uniquely positioned to contribute to developing a National Data Framework to implement Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan in collaboration with relevant stakeholders. From its multilateral partnership, the Accelerator Lab is also positioned to bring in Government agencies, private sector stakeholders, industry association for their participation and organizational buy-in. The Lab will also connect relevant Global Accelerator Labs for knowledge and experience sharing. Previously, UNDP Bangladesh Accelerator Lab collaborated with UNDP Thailand acceleration Lab on sharing learning and experience on community-based tourism. These global knowledge sharing adds tremendous value in such initiatives. Lab will also leverage Artificial Intelligence in implementation of the Tourism Master Plan.
 
https://file.portal.gov.bd/uploads/8ef2a505-c131-4a8f-b6d0-2ac4760cc936/631/6c4/06a/6316c406a9807875210649.pdf

Short “tweet” summary: We would like to tweet what you are working on, can you summarize your challenge in a maximum of 280 characters?
National Data Framework for Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan for Data Innovation and AI-powered sustainable tourism.
#UNDP_BD Accelerator Lab #DataInnovation
#AIpoweredTourism #Bangladesh

Partners
null
Please state the name of the partner:
Bangladesh Tourism Board

What sector does our partner belong to?
Government (&related)

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.
BTB will lead the implementation of Bangladesh tourism master plan With support from. Even to be Bangladesh Accelerator Lab and other stakeholders.

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?
No


Please state the name of the partner:
Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics:

What sector does our partner belong to?
Government (&related)

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.
It is the central data source of the government of Bangladesh. The National framework will be operated in collaboration with BBS

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?
No


Please state the name of the partner:
Tour Operators Owners Association of Bangladesh (TOAB)

What sector does our partner belong to?
Private Sector

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.
As one of the most dynamic body in the tourism and hospitality sector of Bangladesh TOAB will provide instrumental support to this initiative

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?
No


Please state the name of the partner:
Bangladesh Tourist Police

What sector does our partner belong to?
Government (&related)

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.
The Bangladesh Tourist Police, as a key government agency, will play a crucial role in ensuring the safety and security of tourists, fostering a secure and welcoming environment for both domestic and international visitors.

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?
Yes


Please state the name of the partner:
Aspire To Innovate (a2i):

What sector does our partner belong to?
Government (&related)

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.
a2i will extend knowledge and advisory support in implementing final data framework and AI enabled real-time visual visualization.

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?
No
Learning questions
null
Learning question: What is your learning question for this challenge? What do you need to know or understand to work on your challenge statement?
How National Data Framework can be developed as an effective means for implementing Bangladesh Tourism Master Plan?


How AI-powered interventions can impact the tourism landscape in Bangladesh?


How can real-time data visualization support evidence-based policymaking for sustainable and inclusive tourism growth?

To what stage(s) in the learning cycle does your learning question relate?
Explore
Test
Grow

Click to see options
methods: Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning
methods: Data Ethography
methods: Data Visualisation
methods: Horizon Scanning
methods: System Thinking

Usage of methods: Relating to your choice above, how will you use your methods & tools for this learning question? What value do these add in answering your learning question?
An AI-powered Dashboard integrating system thinking, and the mentioned innovation tools are set to revolutionize tourism management in Bangladesh. This innovative platform will provide real time insights into visitor trends, economic impact and environmental sustainability. By leveraging Ai-driven forecasting, policymakers can make data informed decisions, enhance tourism experiences and ensure sustainable growth. The dashboard will serve as a one stop hub fostering collaboration across sectors positioning Bangladesh as a data driven tourism destination

Click to see options
datasources: artificial intelligence
datasources: data from platform
datasources: participatory and collective approach

Existing data gaps: Relating to your choice above, what existing gaps in data or information do these new sources of data addressing? What value do these add in answering your learning question?
Currently, a unified data ecosystem, real-time data for informed decision-making, and insights into tourist behavior and preferences are missing. Data on sustainable tourism practices, promoting eco-friendly initiatives, community-based tourism, location, availability are also not structured and available. Having these data in a structured manner, will enhance decision-making, improve stakeholder coordination, enable targeted marketing, and increase transparency and accountability in the tourism sector, ultimately positioning Bangladesh as a premier global tourist destination.
Closing
null
Early leads to grow: Think about the possible grow phase for this challenge - who might benefit from your work on this challenge or who might be the champions in your country that you should inform or collaborate with early on to help you grow this challenge?
The tourism industry has vast potential to grow and potential to be one of the major contributors to GDP. AI powered national data framework can potentially. Be a game changer in the tourism industry of Bangladesh. Collaboration, commitment and contribution of all relevant stakeholders in developing this visualization platform/ dashboard will enable it as a one stop hub and facilitate data-driven decision making. The growing tourism and hospitality industry, local communities, tourists (national and international) of Bangladesh will highly benefit from this challenge.

"}, {"id": "fa19b906-7c86-4e8a-9f16-7b236d2e6bb8", "txt": "AI has significantly upended the creative sector in recent years, with many artists concerned that it is compromising vital elements of creativity, included through job loss and loss of intellectual property rights amongst other issue areas. This is driven by the rapid rise of AI and resulting misuse and misunderstanding around it. This involves actors such as artists, archivists, curators, copyright lawyers, archaeologists, film/tv producers, actors and more. Currently, many persons involved in the Orange Economy in the Caribbean are apprehensive about AI's impact on the sector, with the resulting undesired effect of persons not embracing AI for good.", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Background: What is the history of your challenge? "}, {"id": "8bf9a24d-d76b-4ea2-9ae8-5011f95b87ee", "txt": "Our Accelerator Lab will leverage its convening power and ability to craft innovation journeys by hosting a Symposium on AI in Caribbean Arts & Heritage. This Symposium will bring together expert panelists before local community members for discuss on subjects such as human rights and access of A.I. in Caribbean arts and heritage, gender & LGBTQIA+ in heritage interpretation through digital technologies, the implications of AI in film and TV, digital technologies and intangible cultural heritage, copyright law in the age of AI nad more. Our Lab needs to work on this challenge based on its unique focus on R&D for sustainable develop and, as AI is an emerging focus in the creative sphere, there is a gap we can fill in terms of generating understanding of the responsible use of AI in the creative sector, which is not widely understood. It is worth investing resources to this challenge as the creative economy represents immense potential as a source of economic growth and diversification in the Caribbean.", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Value proposition: What added value or unique value proposition is your Accelerator Lab bringing to solving this challenge? "}, {"id": "5c9384fd-5f55-4865-8d25-93ea7f0f766a", "txt": "The Acc Lab for BBD & EC will be posting a Symposium on AI in Caribbean Arts & Heritage, discussing its many opportunities and challenges in the creative sector.", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "constraint": 280, "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Short “tweet” summary: We would like to tweet what you are working on, can you summarize your challenge in a maximum of 280 characters?

"}, {"id": "e123ff27-5d34-4fc7-8aee-170054465c1a", "name": "methods", "tags": [{"id": 6393, "key": null, "name": "art of hosting", "type": "methods"}, {"id": 6365, "key": null, "name": "explore", "type": "methods"}, {"id": 438, "key": null, "name": "Future Analysis", "type": "methods"}, {"id": 6709, "key": null, "name": "partnerships", "type": "methods"}], "type": "tag", "level": "meta", "required": true, "constraint": 5, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Innovation methods: What are your top 5 key innovation methods or tools that you are planning to use for this learning question?
"}, {"id": "e15cc79f-c59e-4f31-9609-e93e0a9d7cdf", "txt": "By hosting an AI Symposium on Caribbean Arts & Heritage, we will be engaging key local stakeholders in an innovative manner, leveraging our art of hosting skills and techniques. This will help to weave communities together within the topic of AI, creating potential for partnership and knowledge generation. We will also be exploring the theme of AI in the creative sector, exploring the edges of its potential and pitfalls that are only just starting to appear. This will involve future forecasting and analysis, providing projections of what we anticipate from AI in creative spaces, both globally and regionally.", "name": null, "type": "txt", "level": "media", "fontsize": 1, "required": true, "fontstyle": "normal", "textalign": "left", "fontweight": "normal", "is_excerpt": false, "has_content": true, "instruction": "Usage of methods: Relating to your choice above, how will you use your methods & tools for this learning question? What value do these add in answering your learning question?

"}, {"id": "33633a05-1d65-4157-a292-fda33c6cbdce", "name": "datasources", "tags": [{"id": 495, "key": null, "name": "artificial intelligence", "type": "datasources"}, {"id": 515, "key": null, "name": "cultural probe", "type": "datasources"}, {"id": 6384, "key": null, "name": "engagement with communities", "type": "datasources"}, {"id": 6377, "key": null, "name": "engagement with local stakeholders", "type": "datasources"}], "type": "tag", "level": "meta", "required": true, "has_content": true, "instruction": "New sources of data: What types of new data sources are you using for this learning question?
"}, {"id": "a8ef6e0e-73a6-43dd-8f81-658c59a69c1c", "txt": "By engaging with communities and relevant stakeholders in the digital x Orange Economy space, we will try to fill the many information gaps that exist, such as how many Caribbean persons are actually applying AI to creative work currently. We will also try to gauge sentiment towards AI, measuring how Caribbean persons feel about AI in the context of creativity. full_text:
Exploring Artificial Intelligence in the Orange Economy

Title
null
Please provide a name for your action learning plan.
Exploring Artificial Intelligence in the Orange Economy
Challenge statement
null
Challenge type: If you are working on multiple challenges, please indicate if this is your "big bet" or "exploratory" challenge. 

Please note: we ask you to only submit a maximum of 3 challenges - 1x Big Bet, 2x Exploratory. Each challenge must be submitted individually.
EXPLORATORY

Challenge statement: What is your challenge? (Please answer in specific terms: "Our challenge is that...”.)
Our challenge is that AI presents many potential pitfalls and concerns in the Caribbean arts and heritage sector if not understand and applied responsibly. Conversely, if better understood and used with care, AI can present many opportunities for growth in the Orange Economy.

Background: What is the history of your challenge? What is causing or driving it? Who is involved? How does the current situation look like? What undesired effects does it produce?
AI has significantly upended the creative sector in recent years, with many artists concerned that it is compromising vital elements of creativity, included through job loss and loss of intellectual property rights amongst other issue areas. This is driven by the rapid rise of AI and resulting misuse and misunderstanding around it. This involves actors such as artists, archivists, curators, copyright lawyers, archaeologists, film/tv producers, actors and more. Currently, many persons involved in the Orange Economy in the Caribbean are apprehensive about AI's impact on the sector, with the resulting undesired effect of persons not embracing AI for good.

https://thedocs.worldbank.org/en/doc/83524c72d2551661f645a89526934e55-0460012023/original/S4YE-DiscussionNote-JobsinCreativeEconomy-ImpactofDisruptiveTech-Final-Nov.pdf?deliveryName=FCP_1_DM202199 

https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000391996 

https://www.undp.org/latin-america/blog/ai-revolution-here-how-will-latin-america-and-caribbean-respond

https://www.unesco.org/en/articles/unesco-caribbean-artificial-intelligence-initiative

https://daily.jstor.org/can-artificial-intelligence-be-creative/



https://www.facebook.com/caribbeanhot7tv/videos/opportunities-and-threats-26th-march-2024minister-for-information-dr-ernest-hila/1003241524692347/

https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20241018-ai-art-the-end-of-creativity-or-a-new-movement

https://soundsandcolours.com/subjects/travel/how-ai-is-shaping-the-latin-american-and-caribbean-music-industry-visuals-creativity-and-innovation-77695/

https://www.winnmediaskn.com/creative-disruption-and-innovation-the-focus-of-eccb-8th-growth-and-resilience/



Value proposition: What added value or unique value proposition is your Accelerator Lab bringing to solving this challenge? Why is it your Lab that needs to work on this challenge and not other actors within UNDP, other stakeholders in the country respectively? Why is it worth investing resources to this challenge?
Our Accelerator Lab will leverage its convening power and ability to craft innovation journeys by hosting a Symposium on AI in Caribbean Arts & Heritage. This Symposium will bring together expert panelists before local community members for discuss on subjects such as human rights and access of A.I. in Caribbean arts and heritage, gender & LGBTQIA+ in heritage interpretation through digital technologies, the implications of AI in film and TV, digital technologies and intangible cultural heritage, copyright law in the age of AI nad more. Our Lab needs to work on this challenge based on its unique focus on R&D for sustainable develop and, as AI is an emerging focus in the creative sphere, there is a gap we can fill in terms of generating understanding of the responsible use of AI in the creative sector, which is not widely understood. It is worth investing resources to this challenge as the creative economy represents immense potential as a source of economic growth and diversification in the Caribbean.

Short “tweet” summary: We would like to tweet what you are working on, can you summarize your challenge in a maximum of 280 characters?
The Acc Lab for BBD & EC will be posting a Symposium on AI in Caribbean Arts & Heritage, discussing its many opportunities and challenges in the creative sector.
Challenge classification
null
Click to see options
thematic_areas: AI
thematic_areas: ai ethics
thematic_areas: ai systems
thematic_areas: artificial intelligence
thematic_areas: creative economy
thematic_areas: culture
thematic_areas: digital transformation
thematic_areas: preservation of culture
thematic_areas: orange economy
thematic_areas: intellectual property

Click to see options
sdgs: Decent work and economic growth
sdgs: Industry, innovation and infrastructure
Partners
null
Please state the name of the partner:
Barbados Museum & Historical Society (BMHS)

What sector does our partner belong to?
Civil Society

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.
The BMHS will act as host of the Symposium of Caribbean Arts & Heritage as well as our knowledge partner.

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?
Yes


Please state the name of the partner:
UNICEF Eastern Caribbean

What sector does our partner belong to?
United Nations

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.
UNICEF will partake in the AI Symposium on Caribbean Arts & Heritage as a panelist in the discussion on Youth, Arts Education and AI

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?
No
Learning questions
null
Learning question: What is your learning question for this challenge? What do you need to know or understand to work on your challenge statement?
We want to understand how AI can be responsibly applied to the creative sector in ways that boost the Caribbean Orange Economy.

To what stage(s) in the learning cycle does your learning question relate?
Sense
Explore

Click to see options
methods: art of hosting
methods: explore
methods: Future Analysis
methods: partnerships

Usage of methods: Relating to your choice above, how will you use your methods & tools for this learning question? What value do these add in answering your learning question?
By hosting an AI Symposium on Caribbean Arts & Heritage, we will be engaging key local stakeholders in an innovative manner, leveraging our art of hosting skills and techniques. This will help to weave communities together within the topic of AI, creating potential for partnership and knowledge generation. We will also be exploring the theme of AI in the creative sector, exploring the edges of its potential and pitfalls that are only just starting to appear. This will involve future forecasting and analysis, providing projections of what we anticipate from AI in creative spaces, both globally and regionally.

Click to see options
datasources: artificial intelligence
datasources: cultural probe
datasources: engagement with communities
datasources: engagement with local stakeholders

Existing data gaps: Relating to your choice above, what existing gaps in data or information do these new sources of data addressing? What value do these add in answering your learning question?
By engaging with communities and relevant stakeholders in the digital x Orange Economy space, we will try to fill the many information gaps that exist, such as how many Caribbean persons are actually applying AI to creative work currently. We will also try to gauge sentiment towards AI, measuring how Caribbean persons feel about AI in the context of creativity. We will look to AI itself for some of these answers as well, as well as how AI represents Caribbean iconography and analyzing its benefits and drawbacks.
Closing
null
Early leads to grow: Think about the possible grow phase for this challenge - who might benefit from your work on this challenge or who might be the champions in your country that you should inform or collaborate with early on to help you grow this challenge?
Other SIDS/RBLAC colleagues and teams can benefit from exploration of this challenge. We can collaborate in our regional with tech bodies, academia and cultural institutions.

"}, {"id": "fa19b906-7c86-4e8a-9f16-7b236d2e6bb8", "txt": "In 2024, The Acceleretor Lab has started a major initiative in Kairouan, in the community of Metbasta. After installing 30 bins for organic waste and 5 for sorting plastic, several awareness-raising actions have been organized, particularly with women and on social networks by inviting page holders to participate in this awareness-raising effort. Currently, the majority of waste is no longer thrown into the open but collected and we note that a new collective consciousness has been established among the inhabitants.
The next step will be the valorization of green waste and the formalization of marginalized artisans

full_text:
Valorization of green waste in Metbasta

Title
null
Please provide a name for your action learning plan.

Valorization of green waste in Metbasta
Challenge statement
null
Challenge type: If you are working on multiple challenges, please indicate if this is your "big bet" or "exploratory" challenge. 

Please note: we ask you to only submit a maximum of 3 challenges - 1x Big Bet, 2x Exploratory. Each challenge must be submitted individually.

BIG BET

Challenge statement: What is your challenge? (Please answer in specific terms: "Our challenge is that...”.)

Our challenge is that the valorization of green waste will contribute to reducing inequalities and promoting inclusion

Background: What is the history of your challenge? What is causing or driving it? Who is involved? How does the current situation look like? What undesired effects does it produce?

In 2024, The Acceleretor Lab has started a major initiative in Kairouan, in the community of Metbasta. After installing 30 bins for organic waste and 5 for sorting plastic, several awareness-raising actions have been organized, particularly with women and on social networks by inviting page holders to participate in this awareness-raising effort. Currently, the majority of waste is no longer thrown into the open but collected and we note that a new collective consciousness has been established among the inhabitants.
The next step will be the valorization of green waste and the formalization of marginalized artisans

Survey

A quantitative and qualitative survey was conducted among artisans.



Sociologic study among asrtisans



Value proposition: What added value or unique value proposition is your Accelerator Lab bringing to solving this challenge? Why is it your Lab that needs to work on this challenge and not other actors within UNDP, other stakeholders in the country respectively? Why is it worth investing resources to this challenge?

The Accelerator Lab is working in a rural area that is cut off from many public services, including municipal ones. We fully immersed ourselves with the villagers, gaining the trust of community leaders. This trust capital allows us to carry out experiments, particularly on waste management, which is the village's main problem. We are in the process of developing a major partnership (public sector, private sector, civil society) around this initiative.

Short “tweet” summary: We would like to tweet what you are working on, can you summarize your challenge in a maximum of 280 characters?

Through behavior change and waste management, the Accelerator Lab is building a bridge of trust between citizens and the administration, fostering inclusion, job creation, and access to services.
Challenge classification
null
Click to see options
thematic_areas: informal businesses to formal businesses
thematic_areas: waste management
thematic_areas: waste reduction

Click to see options
sdgs: Decent work and economic growth
sdgs: Climate action
sdgs: Life on land
Partners
null
Please state the name of the partner:

Municipality of Kairouan, Youth regional delegation, Scouts, local CSO, Agriculture regional delegation

What sector does our partner belong to?

Government (&related)

Please provide a brief description of the collaboration.

The Office of Livestock and Pastures.

Is this a new and unusual partner for UNDP?

No
Learning questions
null
Learning question: What is your learning question for this challenge? What do you need to know or understand to work on your challenge statement?

The Office holds data on farmers and livestock breeders who need animal feed. The valorization of green waste will help balance local supply and demand. The Office will conduct chemical analyses to assess the quality of the processed waste, ensure the formalization of producers, and distribute animal feed equitably.

To what stage(s) in the learning cycle does your learning question relate?

Test

Click to see options
methods: (Community) Asset Mapping
methods: Behavioral Insights
methods: Human Centered Design
methods: partnerships
methods: System Thinking

Usage of methods: Relating to your choice above, how will you use your methods & tools for this learning question? What value do these add in answering your learning question?

All these methods are used for immersion in a rural municipality and understanding its internal dynamics. The goal is to build partnerships around waste management to naturally reduce inequalities and promote inclusion.

Click to see options
datasources: academic literature
datasources: administrative records
datasources: citizen experiences
datasources: personas
datasources: waste counting and sorting

Existing data gaps: Relating to your choice above, what existing gaps in data or information do these new sources of data addressing? What value do these add in answering your learning question?

In rural areas, finding data is challenging. It is recommended to rely on direct contact and on-the-ground information collection.
Closing
null
Early leads to grow: Think about the possible grow phase for this challenge - who might benefit from your work on this challenge or who might be the champions in your country that you should inform or collaborate with early on to help you grow this challenge?

an entire community of informal craftswomen (more than 20 families) will benefit, as will the entire surrounding region, discovering that it is possible to transform waste into wealth
